original_data.question:
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?

question_entities.definition: Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Female parents, human or animal.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
Occurring or done each day.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between orange and green, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 570 to 590 nanometers; any of a group of colors of a hue resembling that of ripe lemons and varying in lightness and saturation.
The act of making a very hard effort, possibly at one's limit.

Mechanical devices designed for hoisting or lowering objects or persons from one place to another that is at a different height. Most specialized lifts in healthcare facilities and homes are used to transfer disabled persons and/or to permit them to overcome vertical barriers, typically limited to a difference of about 6 m (20 feet); some are used to get to and from motor vehicles.
The upper part of the human body, or the front or upper part of the body of an animal, typically separated from the rest of the body by a neck, and containing the brain, mouth, and sense organs.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The posture of an individual lying face down.
Something perceptible by one or more of the senses, especially by vision or touch; a material thing.
The organ of sight constituting a pair of globular organs made up of a three-layered roughly spherical structure specialized for receiving and responding to light.
A medial line, especially the medial line or medial plane of the body (or some part of the body).
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
spontaneous or voluntary recreational activities pursued for enjoyment and accessories or equipment used in the activities; includes games, toys, etc.
The posture of an individual lying face up.
The posture of an individual lying face down.

A cognitive disorder marked by an impaired ability to comprehend or express language in its written or spoken form. This condition is caused by diseases which affect the language areas of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical features are used to classify the various subtypes of this condition. General categories include receptive, expressive, and mixed forms of aphasia.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
A specific stage of progression through a sequential process.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
Something perceptible by one or more of the senses, especially by vision or touch; a material thing.
The spatial relation between something and the course along which it points or moves.
Any device that is spherical in shape.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
Nonenzymatically glycosylated proteins or lipids which accumulate in vascular tissue during aging and at an accelerated rate in diabetes.
